pullRequest.body:
The plan is of course to redefine `Order.cof` as the least cardinality of a `Cofinal` set.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,

-->

nodes.body:
### PR summary [2af64c3098](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/18214/commits/2af64c3098443262674dcc6c498670160ee3777d)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.Order.Cofinal`|229|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ Cofinal`
`+ bddAbove_of_not_cofinal`
`+ cofinal_empty_iff`
`+ cofinal_iff_of_orderTop`
`+ cofinal_mono`
`+ cofinal_of_isEmpty`
`+ cofinal_of_not_bddAbove`
`+ cofinal_top`
`+ cofinal_trans`
`+ cofinal_univ`
`+ mem_cofinal_of_isMax`
`+ not_bddAbove_iff_cofinal`
`+ not_cofinal_iff`
`+ not_cofinal_iff_bddAbove`
`+ top_mem_cofinal`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>
Oh, I didn't know that existed. I'm not really sure what that entails. Would it make sense to have a bundled and an unbundled version?

Since cofinal sets have so few properties (you can't take their intersection for example), I would think we don't need the type.

But also, if all you want to do is to show that cofinality is the supremum of cofinal sets, then there is nothing to refactor and you can do it today using `Order.Cofinal`.

Yeah, I realize I could define `Order.cof α = ⨆ s : Order.Cofinal α, #s`.

Still, I would like to have some sort of API - `Order.Cofinal` provides little to work with. I'll ask on Zulip to see what other people think.
What's your plan with respect to `Order.Cofinal`? Do you know it exists?
A set in what kind of type? Maybe add `Let alpha be a type with [LE alpha]`.

I don't think you should be bombarding your reader with Lean notation from the first sentence of the docstring. What about
```suggestion
A set `s` in an order is cofinal when for every `a` there exists an element of `s` greater or equal to it. This
```

pullRequest.title: feat(Order/Cofinal): predicate for cofinal sets

### PR summary [2af64c3098](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/18214/commits/2af64c3098443262674dcc6c498670160ee3777d)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.Order.Cofinal`|229|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ Cofinal`
`+ bddAbove_of_not_cofinal`
`+ cofinal_empty_iff`
`+ cofinal_iff_of_orderTop`
`+ cofinal_mono`
`+ cofinal_of_isEmpty`
`+ cofinal_of_not_bddAbove`
`+ cofinal_top`
`+ cofinal_trans`
`+ cofinal_univ`
`+ mem_cofinal_of_isMax`
`+ not_bddAbove_iff_cofinal`
`+ not_cofinal_iff`
`+ not_cofinal_iff_bddAbove`
`+ top_mem_cofinal`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>
What's your plan with respect to `Order.Cofinal`? Do you know it exists?
Oh, I didn't know that existed. I'm not really sure what that entails. Would it make sense to have a bundled and an unbundled version?

Since cofinal sets have so few properties (you can't take their intersection for example), I would think we don't need the type.

But also, if all you want to do is to show that cofinality is the supremum of cofinal sets, then there is nothing to refactor and you can do it today using `Order.Cofinal`.

Yeah, I realize I could define `Order.cof α = ⨆ s : Order.Cofinal α, #s`.

Still, I would like to have some sort of API - `Order.Cofinal` provides little to work with. I'll ask on Zulip to see what other people think.
